title: How many people will vote in the 2016 presidential election?
preds: People are stoked about this election. Everyone has an opinion about the major party candidates.

Following reports of supposedly record turnout, especially among Latinos, I am editing my forecast.
Nevertheless, I still think it more likely than not that turnout will stay in the same range of 113 to 135 million, though probably closer to 135.
a growing distrust of government and the election system
Updated slightly based on early voting numbers and a prediction I heard from CNN.
Record high early vote turnout in many states.
CNN say early voting will reach 80 million by tues

Using a straight linear regression trend, the further back I go the more results I get over 135 million for 2016.  And while these are two deeply unpopular nominees, passions on both sides are strong.

Early voting is generally up from where it was at this point in 2012, according to reports by Michael McDonald, who knows the numbers as well as anyone.  The official counts on his website are still behind final 2012 numbers, but this is to be expected with some states not having reported numbers for several weeks, and few having reported totals from today (Sunday) which is the biggest in-person early voting day of the cycle. That said, I think we should expect 2016 totals to exceed those from 2012 even if overall turnout is the same, because in general the states have been expanding early voting so a greater percentage of the voting will be done early.  There are some interesting trends though.  Most important, Latino early voting has been up a lot basically everywhere which reports on such demographics.  Latino turnout was only 47% in 2012, so there are a lot of potential new voters among the demographic.  Also, while it has been reported that early voting is down among black North Carolinians, the same is not true in other states, which indicates that this is likely due to changes in election laws and early voting locations and hours, not general enthusiasm.  Third, unaffiliated early voters are up significantly in most states.  Unaffiliated voters are a diverse group, but they are more likely to be younger, which is another demographic that typically has relatively low turnout. I don't want to read too much into early voting numbers but it seems that voters are quite motivated this year, and I'm continuing to shift my expectations of total turnout upwards. https://twitter.com/electproject?lang=en
http://www.electproject.org/early_2016
Although the campaign has been polarizing for many, fear is a powerful motivating force. This will result in at a higher than usual voter turn out

Early voting turn out continues to break records in most of the states where reporting is available. States reporting greater increase of women voting early from 2012: AZ, FL, GA, LA, NC.  Source: @electproject Twitter.  Large Hispanic turn out also reported at record levels in FL, AZ, NV and pockets of TX. TargetSmart via Twitter - just reported national early vote has surpassed 42 million (32 early million votes were cast in 2012) We have to watch for any election day disruptions in terms of computers systems.

- The early voting returns http://www.electproject.org/early_2016 indicate that the turnout is 90% of what it was in 2012 (in terms of total *number* of voters). 
- Now, there are two things to consider 
             1) These numbers are likely to be updated upwards, so that the early voter turnout may match 2012 (in absolute numbers) -- but it may not.  
             2) There are more voters this time around. This means that the turnout, based on just these numbers (in relative terms) is likely to be lower than (or at best the same as)  2012 when it was 57.5%.  - There are an expected 225.8 million eligible voters this year (http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2016/02/03/2016-electorate-will-be-the-most-diverse-in-u-s-history/) and we need 60% turnout to hit 135 million.  - Viewed differently, last time around http://www.electproject.org/early_2016  46.2m early votes were cast out of a total of 128.9 million votes. This time 41.2m early votes have been cast. If the ratios hold, and the 41.2 isn't adjusted upward, this suggests 115 million votes cast this time around.

of the 218 million eligible voters we have less than 150 million actually registered to vote. 
now, i live in mn and we have the highest turnout in the nation. at 75% turnout that's still under 110 million.  http://www.statisticbrain.com/voting-statistics/

According to Pew Research, (http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2016/02/03/2016-electorate-will-be-the-most-diverse-in-u-s-history/), the number of eligible voters is 226 million this year. Assuming turnout stays constant at c.55%, that gives us a baseline of 124 million. Early indications suggest lower voting among black voters, but higher turnout among Latinos and whites. Trump's Get out the Vote movement is also supposedly weaker than in previous elections. The negative campaigning on both sides is likely to depress turnout, as borne out by research, (http://pcl.stanford.edu/common/docs/research/iyengar/1996/goingneg.html). All in all, it looks highly likely that turnout will sit around 124 million, but more likely to go below 113 than above 135.
Early voting seems to show an higher turnout than 2012 . https://electionbettingodds.com/earlyvoting.html
Suppressed votes and voter apathy among blacks and youth is going to keep this below 60%
Dem turnout>, R up, should be 125M

Everyone is afraid the race is tightening; the sheer fear of an opponent win will compel more registered people to vote. Adjusting up to a 1 in 6 chance (from 1 in 20) that it surpasses 135 million. I feel like I'm still underestimating the uncertainty and it should be closer to a toss up.
Some will opt out, but most will vote.
Even if HC supporters have less enthusiasm than BO's and are therefore less likely to show, DT supporters have more enthusiasm than MR's. Assuming that these balance out.
The interest in the election (increasing turnout) will more than offset the decrease from people who stay away because they oppose both major candidates. The result will be a record turnout.
Lower overvall turnout than in 2012 due to aggregate disgust.

when there is significant division in the nation generating strong emotions, people tend to either feel that things are hopeless, and stay home, or make extra effort to express their preferences. I think this election has proved that there is a broad range of subsets of voters who feel they have something to lose by giving up. Hispanics, women, Muslims, blacks, immigrants, and th disabled, not to mention the battered media reporters, have been given many reasons to exact revenge at the polling booths. A couple of weeks of controlled behavior by Trump will not erase the impact of his ill-chosen but revealing comments.
All republican will vote to save America from the Clinton era.
I expect that this highly-polarised and divisive presidential race will ultimately push people out to vote, and therefore result in a high turnout.
People are engaged but not excited.
Both candidates are polarizing so some will stay home.
More than 25 million votes have already been cast with three more days before the polls open.
The absentee and early voting is huge.
Weather for this election day looks good.

I looked up the population that's voting age and multiplied it by the percent that voted in 2004, as I think it will be similar.  I also looked at betting websites that showed how many people they thought would vote.

Early voting numbers have surpassed 2012 levels (data from US Elections Project).  
34 million people have already cast a ballot. 
In 2012, 32.3 million votes were cast ahead of Election Day.  
The report also shows that there's been a decline in early black voters turnout in swing states (North Carolina, Florida).  But there are increases in voting turnout for women, Hispanics and other minority groups. 
(Sources @thehill Twitter), electproject.org)

pro:  the weather forecast for election day looks dry = good
con:  black voters are not turning out at the same rates as in 2008 & 2012

2012 was 129 million according to google.  There are 10 million more people in the us and about 40% of the total population votes (again google, wikipedia).  So my base number is about 133 million (129 + 4).  I can see a lot of things making that number lower (bad weather for instance), but much fewer making that much higher.  I saw widely conflicting reports on how many voters were registered for 2016, but by all accounts more are.  This guys http://targetsmart.com/ quoted 200 million registered voters, which seems really high.  These guys http://www.statisticbrain.com/voting-statistics/ said 146 million, which seems low.  From here http://cdn.bipartisanpolicy.org/wp-content/uploads/sites/default/files/2012%20Voter%20Turnout%20Full%20Report.pdf you can see 153 million registered in 2012, so maybe 160 million registered voters in 2016 as a base number.
Total voting age population is projected to be 244.263 million. Projecting against the last two presidential years turnout should be about 54%. It only requires ~+1.5% to break 135.

The largest voter turnout was in 2008 with 131M voters. I think that was an extraordinary occasion. In 2012 voter turnout was down again. Considering the extremely low favorability ratings that the 2 major candidates have this year I do not think that we will surpass the 2008 numbers of 131M but we will not go back to 1990s numbers. There's also a small possibility that Latinos and African-Americans turnout in large numbers and that could push the number past 135M (slow chance though).
Record early voting, and warmer weather likely.
until there is serious voter registration reform/more effort to make voting easier/less blatantly discriminatory laws we finna be stuck in the 50s
Revised based off of me being stupid and doing math wrong previously. Question is whether over 60% of pop. will vote. I believe yes based on high interest by the youth
Turnout is likely to remain on track with earlier elections, with both low enthusiasm for candidates and important differences between them (enemy of my enemy factor).
Downgrading due to what I am seeing from people not wanting to cast a vote for either candidate, as well as rumblings about not voting as a protest vote.

Voting Eligible Population projected to be 225.8 million to 231.5 million.
Voting Age Population projected to be 251.1 million. http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2016/02/03/2016-electorate-will-be-the-most-diverse-in-u-s-history/ http://www.electproject.org/2016g If at least 53.7% of VAP turns out to vote, basket 3 wins. That doesn't seem like too high a hurdle. Or if about 58% of VEP turns out, basket 3 wins. That would require higher turnout than 2012. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voter_turnout_in_the_United_States_presidential_elections http://bipartisanpolicy.org/library/2012-voter-turnout/ There have been 12-13 million people added to voting eligible population since 2012. But I'm thinking that a lot of those are young people, who historically have low voter participation. And a disproportionate number are ethnic minorities, who also have historically low voter participation (see Pew article).  I'm still thinking that basket 2 looks more likely.

More than 200 million people are now registered to vote in the country, 50 million more than were registered eight years ago, and more than 70 million more than were registered in the late ’90s.
http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2016/10/a-historic-200-million-americans-are-registered-to-vote.html Historical turnout last 3 elections have averaged 56%.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voter_turnout_in_the_United_States_presidential_elections Reuters estimates 60%.
http://www.reuters.com/statesofthenation/ That gives between 120 and 112 million as the baseline estimate. "New data from the Pew Research Center indicated that more than 4 million ballots had been cast by Saturday, and that before November 8 arrives, the advance voting total may well swell beyond 50 million, the most ever. That would be a significant proportion of the overall voter turnout, which probably will be at least 130 million ballots."
http://www.voanews.com/a/millions-americans-already-voted-twenty-sixteen-elections/3562231.html I revised upwards to 130-140 million, with a projected turnout of 65-70%.

"New data from the Pew Research Center indicated that more than 4 million ballots had been cast by Saturday, and that before November 8 arrives, the advance voting total may well swell beyond 50 million, the most ever. That would be a significant proportion of the overall voter turnout, which probably will be at least 130 million ballots."

Instead of expanding the electorate, Bannon and his team are trying to shrink it. ‘We have three major voter suppression operations under way,’ says a senior official. They’re aimed at three groups Clinton needs to win overwhelmingly: idealistic white liberals, young women, and African Americans. Trump’s invocation at the debate of Clinton’s WikiLeaks e-mails and support for the Trans-Pacific Partnership was designed to turn off Sanders supporters. The parade of women who say they were sexually assaulted by Bill Clinton and harassed or threatened by Hillary is meant to undermine her appeal to young women. And her 1996 suggestion that some African American males are ‘super predators’ is the basis of a below-the-radar effort to discourage infrequent black voters from showing up at the polls—particularly in Florida ...
IMHO, there is a possibility of a record low turnout.
135 million is ~62%, turnout hasn't been that high since the 60's. I think Trump vs Hillary will slightly depress rather than increase turnout. Obama had mid 50s.

consensus, including me, is too high.

http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/enthusiasm-early-voting-affect-turnout-presidential-election/story?id=43013278 "As a percent of voting age population it will be low, probably lower than the past four or five presidential elections," [ABC News political analyst] Dowd said. "Net total will set a record though." "The latest ABC News tracking poll released this morning shows that while 56 percent of Clinton's supporters said that they are voting for her because they want to see her in the White House, 54 percent of Trump supporters said that they are voting for him more as a referendum on Clinton than as a reflection of their view on Trump directly. "When you look at the enthusiasm numbers for each candidate they are below 2012, 2008, and 2004," Dowd said. "An estimated 34 percent of voters are expected to vote early, according to Michael McDonald, a political science professor at the University of Florida and fellow at Brookings Institution. 
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  This question asks about the absolute number of voters, not percent turn-out, so the increase of 50m in registered voters, as well as is the fact that there is now a record number of registered voters (200m+), is important information.

I believe I screwed up in my initial estimate, as I was comparing incompatible numbers.  A mess! So I am going to start over with a comparable set of numbers, all based from this website:
http://www.electproject.org/home/voter-turnout/voter-turnout-data Voting Eligible Population (VEP) has risen from 203.5 million in 2004 to 227.2 in 2014.  To maintain this path, this number has gone up about 2.5 million per year.  So a baseline VEP for 2016 would be about 232.2 million.   Now I will point out that my number is significantly different than that cited by PEW, and listed under question information.  I believe that number is 224 million.  I would exercise caution using that number and using participation rates from the U.S. election project website.  In order to avoid yet another inconsistency, I am abandoning the PEW number and using U.S. election project numbers exclusively.   Average turnout of VEP for presidential general elections for 2004, 2008, 2012 has been 60.0%.   Therefore, a mid-range number for total turnout in 2016 would be 139.3 million, which is admittedly significantly higher than the 129.1 experienced in 2012.  Say its at the low end of turnover (58.5% for 2012), we still have just under 135 million.  My bet is the higher turnout number is more likely because this is an election that has seen a lot of contention and effort to bring out the vote, with a lot of new registrants.  But even if we have lower end turnout for a presidential election, we are probably going to be very close to 135 million.   So I am switching (!) from 90/10 to 10/90.  For those that went along with me, I am VERY sorry.  Totally my error.

Historically % of the voting age population has been in the 50-60% range per https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voter_turnout_in_the_United_States_presidential_elections. 50% is about 113mm, and 60% is about 135mm.

Taking a look at early voting trends (already going on in 32 states).  Only a few report on numbers.  Early voting just started in Texas and Dallas reported record numbers of 58,329+ on the first day. Dallas had 32,512 in 2012 and 34,415 in 2008 on the first day of early voting.  Houston also set a record today with 63,000 vs 47,000 in 2012  (source @CBSDFW Twitter ). Travis County reported double the numbers of early voters than it had in 2012; Harris County had 67,471 today vs 47,093 in 2012 ( Source @texastribune Twitter)  When checked for population growth, these counties had average 8-10% growth, and 42% vote increase. Florida's early voting started today.  Reports showed that, at least for early voting, 99% more Hispanics have already voted than 2012 (Source @buzzfeednews Twitter)
More than 33%

As for Utah, 33% more Democrats have cast early ballots than expected (Salt Lake Tribune)
In Nevada, 11% of registered voters have already voted Increasing my forecast based on number of newly registered voters for this election (over 50 million).  It only takes 4 million more votes than 2008 to get above the 135M mark. Of course that it is tricky to use 2008 as a baseline given that was the year Pres. Obama was elected. But given pop. growth and growth in number of people registered, I will side on a high turn out.

In my earlier post using Census Dept data, I calculated that in 2008 voter turnout was 89.6% of registered voters. http://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/politics-government/election/article109216532.html
Data for 2012 from above linked article:

Total voted = 133m
turnout rate of registered voters = 86.8% 86.8% of 200m registered voters = 173.6m

Linear regression last 21 presidential election years yielded 128 million; then decided to throw away everything but the last 4 elections for a probability distribution. Didn't take into account registered voters, eligible voters, current population size; then checked the area under a normal probability distribution. That said, there's a probability that Trump supporters will turn out less due to Trump's vague allegations of fraud, and probability that not Trump supporters will turn out in excess out of fear. With stronger third party support, more people may feel that they have a chance for a protest vote to have more utility, even if it doesn't result in a third party candidacy.

I went to this website to find the percent of registered voters who voted in 2008.
http://www.census.gov/data/tables/2008/demo/voting-and-registration/p20-562-rv.html If I read the chart correctly, there were 146,311 registered voters in 2008 and 131,144 voted.  That makes a turnout rate of 89.6%. According to orchidny @ http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/357331, there's more than 200m registered voters in the US now. If more than 135m vote, that would represent a turnout rate of 67.6% of registered voters.  Why would the turnout rate this year be more than 20% below the rate in 2008? Am I missing something here?

News this week reported that the US had reached 200 million registered voters for the first time in history. That figure counted 50 million NEW voters since 2008. That's staggering.  Anger has proven to be a stronger motivator for people going out to the polls than most other factors. I think it's safe to assume this will translate into a large number of women voting this year. But so it's true for millions of Trump supporters who follow his rhetoric of a rigged system, electoral fraud, and media bias.  So, given the recent number of newly registered voters, I will adjust my forecast
Much interest in the two candidates, and the cultures they represent
Voter turnout in the primaries was almost a record high (next to 2008)
This election is polarizing and producing strong emotions in people. That will pull more people to vote
Seeing heavy early voting so far. Georgia may have record early turnout. Seems unlikely to have low turnout.
Well, considering hearing about all of the recent voter fraud and dead people who registered to vote, the number could be higher than ever before

Early voting seems to be heavy so far. 
Curious why people think there's so little chance of less than 113 million, though.

Given the so called "civil war" within the Republican Party, one may reasonably expect more abstentions than usual.  Many people who had started out as Trump supporters are now said to be considering not voting at all given the recent scandals involving the candidate. But some also talk about the Trump silent supporters who may come out on Election Day.  I don't put a lot of weight on that last theory because in such a highly incendiary and unorthodox campaign, people are being everything but silent about their political opinions. At the same time, we cannot discount the possibility of many people being shamed into not openly supporting Trump given his controversial remarks.  I still don't see a significantly large silent number of people coming out of the shadows on this election and becoming a deciding phenomenon.  The primaries saw record turn out numbers (previous highs were from 1980 elections).  But history shows that "once a party's candidate is locked up, voter turn out in subsequent contests tends to fall off" http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2016/03/08/so-far-turnout-in-this-years-primaries-rivals-2008-record/ Here are the voter turn out numbers since 1980:  Year        VAP              Turn out     % of  VAP
1980	163,945	     86,497	52.8%
1984	173,995	     92,655	53.3%
1988	181,956	     91,587	50.3%
1992	189,493	     104,600	55.2%
1996	196,789	     96,390	49.0%
2000	209,787	     105,594	50.3%
2004	219,553	     122,349	55.7%
2008	229,945	     131,407	57.1%
2012	235,248	     129,235	54.9% Even with expected abstention, it seems most reasonable to expect turn out within the 113-135 million range. I see more probability in going above, then below that.

My analysis for this forecast was a very poor effort.  Please see my newer forecast, which is at least a logical and consistent estimation.

4 Reasons: 1) There's signs that the turnout in TX may be higher than usual. see:  http://www.caller.com/news/state/state-bureau/low-turnout-texas-shows-signs-of-heightened-interest-in-2016-elections-3ed60a88-6393-644b-e053-01000-397129791.html 2)  Hispanic voters have had lower than average turnout rates, but there's evidence that they are becoming more engaged this time due to DT's rhetoric,  especially in NV & FL where there's Hispanic candidates on the ballot. 3)  each of the 3 debates (2 for Pres, 1 for VP) have garnered record numbers of viewers even though tv viewing rates are down.  I don't think people would set aside 90 min x 3 to watch a debate and then NOT go to the polls. 4)  some polling places are reporting record numbers of early & absentee voters.  see:  http://www.lancastereaglegazette.com/story/news/local/2016/10/15/early-voting-turnout-doubles-polls/92060098/

Today it is clear that constituents are not interested in either candidates and other than the fringes polarized to either side the independents are unlikely to vote for a candidate and in many cases not vote at all.  The greatest turnout in recent history was a due to a venomous hatred and blame of George W. Bush as well as a republican turnout that was more agains President Obama.  In this case it seems likely that both candidates will keep people home rather than incite record turnout.

http://tucson.com/news/national/govt-and-politics/for-donald-trump-low-turnout-strategy-unlikely-to-work/article_24f60f8e-732d-5da8-ab04-d263dc20bbf1.html "Ayres, the Republican pollster, said elections that are "reasonably close" and involve "clear consequences" usually generate higher turnout. "I'd say this election meets both standards," he said. " . . . . Voter registration isn't yet complete, but population figures suggest normal turnout will again top 130 million. "Early voting is on the rise, with Clinton's campaign pushing supporters in that direction. More than 750,000 ballots have been cast already, and an estimated 45 million votes are expected before Election Day. Early-voting trends in two must-win states for Trump, North Carolina and Florida, are favorable to Clinton. In both states, there are notable gains among black and Hispanic voters, groups Trump needs to remain cool to Clinton. "The Republican National Committee and individual Senate and House campaigns also have an extensive "ground game" of staffers and volunteers working to identify and encourage supporters. So has the political network of the Koch brothers, the conservative billionaire businessmen.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  This is the first I've read about a GOP effort to GOTV, and the statement by Ayres rings true with me.  Inching up 5%.

https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2016/10/14/the-clinton-camp-predicts-record-turnout-which-is-not-an-earth-shaking-prediction/ "We've been very confident since the time we saw the very first numbers on day one that we would see the largest turnout in American history," Hillary Clinton's campaign manager Robby Mook said on Thursday. "We will see more ballots cast in this election than any presidential election than ever before."
. . . 
"Only six times since 1856 has turnout gone down election-over-election. Why? 
. . .
"The most votes cast were cast in 2008, when over 131 million cast a ballot. That turnout fell a bit in 2012. But since 2012, the country has added another 24 million people, according to Census Bureau data aggregated by WolframAlpha. So in 2008, about 43 percent of the total population cast a ballot. To top that total in 2016, only 40 percent need to do so. That's not a given, but it's easier than it may seem. We passed that mark in 2004, 2008 and 2012. "Given how unpopular both Clinton and Donald Trump are, it's safe to wonder if people will be inspired to go to the polls. (Trump's new campaign strategy seems pretty focused on driving those numbers down, given that he hasn't figured out how to move his numbers upward and keep them there.) What we've seen, though, is that a lot of people plan on voting because they oppose the other candidate. It's safe to say that a number of Republicans will turn out to try and keep Clinton from winning, and a lot of Democrats will do the same to stymie Trump.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  I think that there's a lot of interest in House & Senate races this year which will help bring people to the polls, but it doesn't sound like the Trump campaign has much of a GOTV effort going.  Perhaps these 2 forces will balance each other out, leaving us with an increase due to the increase in the number of voters.
early voting numbers suggest that turnout could be a record
Widespread dissatisfaction with both candidates, combined with a fairly clear lead for Clinton means little incentive to get out and vote.

Average voting turnout over past four US presidential elections = 122 million (A). Estimated voting age population in 2016 based on linear growth = 245,325 (B). Average voter turnout percentage over past four US elections = 54.5% (C). B*C = 133 million. Both candidates least likeable in US history, reverse estimate down.

and for 2016 it was 29%, 60% of population, or 131,400,000,voting seems very possible (how very in probabilities? - that I'm not sure about.) Would really like to know if voter registration rolls have spiked this past month. This is
 the deadline to register to vote that might capture that apathetic 40 million people who normally don't vote and  would likely vote for trump.

There would need to be a 59.8% turnout of the voting age population to reach 135 million voters this year. That hasn't happened since the 1960s. 50% turnout needed to fall below 113 million. That happened in 1996, but that was Bill Clinton's second term. I would not expect such low turnout for a new president.

Early voting increases markedly compared to the same time in 2012: http://www.cbsnews.com/news/early-voting-surge-benefits-hillary-clinton/ Some of this could be due to a general trend towards more early voting in the U.S., but I'll take it as a weak sign to bolster my hypothesis that the the divisiveness of the candidates will drive more, not less voter to the polls than last time. Therefore strengthening Option 3 by 1 point. I will be interested figures of more states. If this trend (which in the article was only analyzed for important swing states) holds on a broader level and when more states start their early voting, I will become more bullish on my current analysis.

Increasing >135 from 20 to 40 and reducing middle option by the same amount. However, the fact that the first debate between them was watched by a record number of viewers suggests the turnout is not going to be low.

There is an interesting article on 538: http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/missing-white-voters-could-elect-trump-but-first-they-need-to-register/ It provides numbers for key battleground states on voter registration. The number of registered voters seems to have increased by around 4.5-5% on average. It stands to reason that an increase in registered voters should translate to an increase in votes cast. The increase noted by 538 is also consistent with the estimate of the increase of the number of eligible voters by Pew, which I cited in an earlier comment (http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/317032). With 129 million votes cast in 2012, an increase of 5% would result in 135.45 million votes this year, leading me to give slightly more weight to Option 3, especially as I continue to assume that turnout will gain, not suffer from the divisiveness of the candidates and the campaign (again, this is based more on gut feeling than on science, so if anyone has actual scientific facts on this issue, please let me know).

Using population data and voter data from sources below.  Start with population for 2016.  Estimate the % of population that is of voting age by regression over elections since 2000.  This has been creeping up in a fairly linear fashion, so estimating 77.35% of the population will be of voting age.  Of these people, the number eligible to vote is about 92.3%, which has been pretty steady, so this is just an average since 2000.  Of eligible voters, we're seeing 55% to 61% turnout.  Average of the past 4 presidential elections gives about 58%.  Multiply it all together and you have about 135.3 million, so just slightly over the top threshold.  I guess you can factor in whether you think this will be higher than average or lower than average, but that's a toss up for me. Interesting WaPo article and poll: https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/clinton-holds-lead-over-trump-in-new-poll-but-warning-signs-emerge/2016/09/10/800dee0c-76c8-11e6-b786-19d0cb1ed06c_story.html?hpid=hp_hp-top-table-main_poll-12am%3Ahomepage%2Fstory My takeaway: while the article talks about a "turnout challenge", this is based purely on the enthusiasm of the Clinton supporters in relation to Trump supporters. The overall state of the campaign seems to be comparable with 2012 (a similar share of registered voters have made up their minds about who to vote for) with the exception of how hated the candidates are among supporters of the opponent. "8 in 10 Trump supporters feel Clinton would do real damage to the country as president, while 83 percent of Clinton supporters feel the same way about Trump." One noteworthy stat: 81% of registered voters are "Absolutely certain to vote". In 2012 the same question was asked at about the same time in the campaign and 83% answered with "Absolute certain" (https://www.washingtonpost.com/page/2010-2019/WashingtonPost/2012/09/11/National-Politics/Polling/release_126.xml) about 86% of registered voters went to the polls in that year. We don't know for sure how many registered voters there are currently. This data is only collected after the election every two years. But extrapolating from the 2012 figures by 5% (the same amount I used in my last forecast to extrapolate eligible voters, based on Pew Research numbers), 156,043,341 Americans are estimated to be registered. Assuming that a similar trend to 2012 holds, we can expect 84% of registered voters to go to the polls, which would result in 131,076,406.51 voters, well short of Option 3. This is all very shaky math and we are within the opinion polls error margin here. I will nonetheless change my forecast slightly towards Option 2.

Voter turnout has not been less than 113m since 2000, and has generally increased along with population growth. Pop growth is at about .03% from 2012-2016, somewhat larger than the .028% it increased from 2008-2012. In 2012, voter turnout slightly declined while VAP increased (possibly due to party choices). It seems more people are frustrated with the options this voting season, and so I cannot see it passing 135 million, could end up close though.

Baby Boomers and Millennials are now the two largest generations in the voting-age population. One is in the habit of voting (and interested in protecting their benefits); the other isn't. And it takes younger voters to push the total over 60%. If you look at the last five presidential elections when participation exceeded that mark, you can see the tone of the times.  A charismatic young senator with a media-magnet wife, appealing children and a hopeful, optimistic and progressive vision burst upon the scene in both 1960 and 2008, energizing first-time voters.  1968 and 2004 were war referendums, the first driven by the Baby Boomers growing rejection of Vietnam policy, the second by their objection to the war in Iraq (an echo-Boom, of sorts), which pulled the now-overlooked Gen X into the fray. In 1964, civil rights took center stage, and motivated young people both to protest and to vote. That energy is present again, but has no Lyndon Johnson around which to focus. Sec. Clinton and Mr. Trump may collectively appall the reliable (e.g. older) portion of the electorate into  the booth, but neither will entice voters young enough to correctly conclude that the system is "rigged" against them.

Voter turnout for the primaries was 28.5%, only 1.9% lower than 2008. In 2008 the general election had 58.3% voter turnout, resulting in roughly 131 million voters. Estimating the 2016 voting age population at 245.5 million (around 10 million more than in 2012), and assuming 58% turnout for the general election, this results in over 142 million voters. Also, fitting voter turn out data from 1960 with an exponential curve (to model population growth), the predicted voter turn out is barely over 135 million, not taking into account the surge in voter turn out this year so far.

The vote totals have consistently been between 120 and 125 million for the last three cycles. It hasn't been below 120m since 2000, and I view a lower vote total as pretty unlikely, even if Trump is uninspiring for Republicans. On the other hand, to see a jump of 10 million for this year is also unlikely.

This is the most complete historical data series I found on election turnout and eligible voter count: http://www.electproject.org/home/voter-turnout/voter-turnout-data Pew research estimates that total eligible voters will increase by 5% compared to 2012: http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2016/02/03/2016-electorate-will-be-the-most-diverse-in-u-s-history/ Pew uses a slightly different definition (or different baseline data) of "eligible voter", but the 5% should still be a workable estimate for 2012-2016 trend. Based on this I expect a total of 233,597,816 voters in Nov 2016. "Less than 113 million" (Option 1) would thus represent a turnout of < 48.7%, "Between 113 million and 135 million, inclusive" (Option 2) a turnout of between 48.7% and 57.8% and "More than 135 million" (Option 3) a turnout of > 57.8%. Option 1 would be the lowest turnout in U.S. history (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voter_turnout_in_the_United_States_presidential_elections#Other_eligibility_factors). Option 2 would underperform the last three elections, but be in the range of most elections since 1968. Option 3 would present a continuation of the voter turnout figures seen since 2004. Based purely on this historical analysis I would estimate the chance of Option 1 and 1%, Option 2 at 49% and Option 3 at 50%. Factors driving voter turnout seem to surprisingly badly understood (https://www.utwente.nl/bms/csd/research/Smets%20en%20Van%20Ham%202013.pdf). There is no scientific consensus on how the current campaign will influence voter turnout and there is no historical example, either. Based on my own interpretation of turnout figures in multiple countries, I will argue that there are primarily two factors that could influence the turnout in the coming elections positively: sympathy or aversion to one of the candidates. Sympathy seems out of the question, given both candidates' high unfavorables, but aversion is obviously strong.  I think that aversion to both Clinton and Trump will drive participation in the polls of the supporters of their respective opponents, as both candidates and their campaigns will succeed in painting a picture of dire consequences, should their opponent be elected. This will be especially true if the election appears to be close. Given current estimates, Clinton has a decent, though not huge, lead in the polls. I will therefore put my forecast at 1% (Option 1), 39% (Option 2) and 60% (Option 3) and will adjust based on developments in the polls and other related information.

Historical turnout:
10 of the last 25 presidential elections have had turnout over 60% (by VEP stats).  Turnout has not been below 50% since 1924. Third party effect:
Ross Perot's candidacy in 1992 seems to be the only case where a strong third party candidate seems to have increased voter turnout, and when he ran again in 1996, turnout returned to around the same level as 1988.  The conventional political wisdom is that Gary Johnson is not an especially strong third party candidate and is mostly drawing support from disaffected Clinton and Trump voters.  The one effect I could see Johnson having would be preventing turnout from falling too low by giving disaffected voters another option. Campaign negativity:
Both candidates have high feelings of negativity surrounding them, and the campaign has already been fairly negative.  Research on negative campaign ads seems to be quite mixed [1], but because Clinton and Trump are more disliked among their own party's voters than the typical nominee, I think the effect is more likely to be negative. Trump effect?:
Conventional wisdom holds that Trump's uniqueness as a candidate has an appeal to a different set of voters than a traditional Republican.  However, POLITICO analysis [2] showed that he was attracting voters who normally voted in the general to the election into the primary, not entirely new voters.  The 1968 election, in which Wallace tried to appeal to far-right groups and as a"law and order" candidate, also had pretty typical turnout for the era, suggesting that some of Trump's similar messages are unlikely to turnout any large group of new voters. If turnout from 2012 holds steady and 55% of the 10.7 new voters estimated by Pew turn up to vote then the total number of voters will be very close to 135 million.  I think it is more likely to be below this, but turnout being below 113 million would be a huge shift which I can't see happening. [1] http://journalistsresource.org/studies/politics/ads-public-opinion/negative-political-ads-effects-voters-research-roundup
[2] http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2016/05/donald-trump-2016-polling-turnout-early-voting-data-213897

Trump could bring out a lot of first time voters, both for and against him. On the other hand, a large number of previously regular voters may be turned off by this year's main candidates (and may not make the effort to essentially waste their vote on a third party)
